The MahÄyÄna is established with the three realms being only consciousness, because a sÅ«tra says the three realms are only mind. Mind, thought, consciousness, and cognition are different names.

Here, mind is said to include thought and mental factors. It only excludes external objects and does not eliminate the associated [factors]. When internal consciousness arises, it appears as if external objects, like seeing hair, flies, etc. due to an eye disease. There is absolutely no real meaning here.
Regarding this meaning, there are objections.
The verse says:
If consciousness has no real object, then place and time would be definite,
Continuity would be indefinite, and function would not be able to be accomplished.
The treatise says:
What is the meaning of this?

If apart from consciousness there are real external dharmas such as form, and the consciousness of form, etc. arises without relying on form, etc., why is it that this consciousness can arise in some places but not everywhere?
Why does consciousness sometimes arise in this place and not at all times?
If there are many continua in the same place and time, why is it not certain that consciousness arises for only one of them?
It is like a person with blurred vision seeing hairs, flies, and so forth. This consciousness does not arise without blurred vision.

What other reason is there that the hairs, etc. seen by those with blurred vision have no function of hairs, etc., the food, drink, swords, staffs, poisons, clothes, etc. obtained in dreams have no function of food, etc., and the fragrant cities, etc. have no function of cities, etc.?

The function of other hairs, etc. is not nonexistent. If they are really the same as external objects such as form, etc., and there is only internal consciousness appearing like external objects, then definite places, definite times, indefinite continua, and things with functions would all not be established.
They are not all not established.
Verse:
Like dreams, places and times are definite. Like ghosts, bodies are indefinite.
Like dreams, they have the function of harm.
Commentary:

The phrase â€œlike a dreamâ€ means like what is seen in a dream. This means that although there is no real external object in a dream, there are places where one sees villages, gardens, men, women, and so on, but not everywhere.
In those places, sometimes one sees villages, gardens, and so on, but not all the time.
Therefore, although there is no real external object apart from consciousness, it is not the case that place and time are not determined.
The phrase â€œlike a ghostâ€ shows that it is like a hungry ghost.
A river filled with pus is called a river of pus, just as a vessel filled with ghee is called a vessel of ghee.
This means that hungry ghosts, due to the ripening of the same karma, gather in many bodies and all see a river of pus, not that only one of them sees it.
The word â€œand so onâ€ shows that they may see excrement and so on, and see sentient beings holding swords and staves to block and guard it so that they cannot eat it.
Therefore, although there is no real external object apart from consciousness, the meaning of the non-determination of many continuums is established.
Moreover, although the objects in a dream are unreal, they have the function of losing semen and blood and so on.
Therefore, although there is no real object apart from consciousness, the meaning of false function is established.
In this way, the four meanings such as definite place are established based on various analogies.
Next, a verse says:
All are like the hells, with the same perception of jailers and so forth,
Capable of causing harm, therefore the four meanings are all established.
The treatise says:
It should be known that in this case, one analogy of hell illustrates that all the meanings such as definite place are established.
The phrase like the hells illustrates the beings in the hells who experience the suffering of being harmed.

That is to say, although in the hells there are no real beings belonging to the category of jailers and so forth, due to the power of the dominant effect of the same karma of those beings, in the same place and at the same time, many continuums all together see there are jailers, dogs, crows, iron mountains, and other things coming to their places to cause harm.
Because of this, although there are no real objects apart from consciousness, the four meanings such as definite place are all established.
Why do you not admit that the wardens of the hells are real sentient beings?
Because it is unreasonable.
They are not included among the hell beings, because they do not experience the suffering experienced by the hell beings.
If they are mutually oppressive, they cannot be considered hell beings.
If the wardens are the same in size, strength, and power, they cannot be mutually fearful. They cannot endure the suffering of the burning iron ground, so how can they oppress others there?
If they are not hell beings, they should not be born there. How is it that animals exist in heaven, and likewise in hell there are animals and hungry ghosts as wardens?
This is not a correct explanation.
A verse says:
Animals in heaven are not like that in hell.
Because the animals and hungry ghosts you posit do not experience that suffering.
The treatise says:

Animals that are born in the heavens must have karma that can attract the instruments of pleasure there. When born there, they definitely experience the pleasure produced by those instruments. The wardens of hell do not experience the suffering produced by the instruments in hell. Therefore it is not accepted that animals and hungry ghosts are born in the hells.

If that is so, then it must be accepted that by the power of the karma of those in the hells, different primary elements are produced, giving rise to differences in form, appearance, size, and strength. There, the names of wardens, etc. are established, and in order to frighten them, various transformations appear, such as moving the hands and feet, etc. The differences in function are like the mountain of rams sometimes separating and sometimes joining, and the iron forest thorns sometimes lowering and sometimes raising.
It is not that these things do not exist at all, but it is not reasonable.
The verse says:
If it is accepted that by the power of karma, different primary elements are produced,
Why not accept that such transformations arise from consciousness?
The treatise says:
Why is it not accepted that consciousness transforms in this way by the power of karma, while it is held that the primary elements do so?
Furthermore, a verse says:
The remaining perfuming of karma is in other places, and the fruit is grasped as existing in other places.
The perfumed consciousness has fruit, but why is it not allowed to exist?
The treatise says:

It is reasonable to allow that the perfuming of karma exists in the continuity of consciousness, not in other places. If there is no perfumed consciousness, you would not allow the transformation of fruit, but you grasp that there is fruit in a place without perfuming. What is the reason for this?
The teaching is the cause, which means that if only consciousness appears as form, etc., without separate form, etc., the Buddha should not say that there are places of form, etc.
This teaching is not the cause, because it has a separate meaning.
A verse says:
The World-Honored One, based on the beings to be transformed,ğŸ”½Secretly intends to say that there are places of form, etc.,
Like beings born by transformation.
The treatise says:

Just as the Buddha said that there are sentient beings born by transformation, he only spoke with an ulterior intention, relying on the uninterrupted continuity of mind that can go to the next world, and did not say that there really are sentient beings born by transformation.
He said that there is no sentient being or self, but only dharmas and causes, and therefore spoke of the sense bases of form, etc.
The sÅ«tras are also like this. Relying on the teachings that those to be converted are inclined to accept, he spoke with an ulterior intention, and not because they really exist separately.
On what ulterior intention did he rely in speaking of the ten such as form?
Verse:
Consciousness is born from its own seeds, appearing as the semblance of an external realm.
In order to establish the internal and external sense bases, the Buddha spoke of them as ten.
Commentary:
What does this passage mean?

The consciousness appearing as form is born from its own seeds, from the transformation and differentiation of the union of conditions. The Buddha, in accordance with those seeds and the form that appears, respectively spoke of them as the eye sense base and the form sense base.

In the same way, the consciousness that appears as tangibles arises from its own seeds through the transformation of conditions. The Buddha, based on those seeds and the tangibles that appear, respectively teaches them as the body sense base and the tangible sense base.
Based on this hidden meaning, he teaches the ten such as form.
What benefit is there in this hidden teaching?
A verse says:
Based on this teaching, one can enter the non-self of the individual,
And based on other teachings, one can enter the non-self of grasped phenomena.
The treatise says:
Based on this teaching of the twelve sense bases, those who receive the teaching can enter the non-self of the individual.

This means that if one understands that the six consciousnesses arise from the combination of the six sense organs and the six sense objects, and that there is no seer up to no knower, then those who should accept the teaching of the non-self of sentient beings can awaken to the non-self of sentient beings.
Furthermore, based on this other teaching of consciousness-only, those who receive the teaching can enter the non-self of grasped phenomena.

If one knows that consciousness only appears as form, etc., and that in this there are no dharmas of form, etc., then one who is to accept the teaching of no self in dharmas is able to penetrate the nonexistence of a self in dharmas.
If one knows that dharmas are nonexistent in all modes, then consciousness only is also ultimately nonexistent. What is established?

It is not that one knows that dharmas are nonexistent in all modes and is said to penetrate the nonexistence of a self in dharmas. However, one understands that the self-nature and differences of dharmas as imagined by the foolish are nonexistent, and this is called penetrating the nonexistence of a self in dharmas. It is not that the realm of the Buddhas, the ineffable true nature of dharmas, is also totally nonexistent and is called the nonexistence of a self in dharmas.
The nature of this consciousness only that is grasped by other consciousnesses is also nonexistent, and this is called the nonexistence of a self in dharmas.

If it were not so, and the objects grasped by other consciousnesses did exist, then the principle of consciousness only would not be established, because it would be admitted that the other consciousnesses have real objects.

For this reason, the teaching of consciousness only is established, which universally causes understanding and entry into the selflessness of all dharmas, because it does not deny the existence of natures in all ways.

How do we know that the Buddha spoke of the existence of form, etc., with this kind of hidden meaning, and that there are no separate real external dharmas such as form, etc., that serve as objects for consciousnesses of form, etc.?
A verse says:
Because those objects are not one, nor are they many subtle atoms,
Nor are they aggregations, etc., because subtle atoms are not established.
The treatise says:
What is this referring to?

If real external places such as form, etc., actually exist as objects for consciousnesses of form, etc., then these external objects would either be one, like the part-possessing form grasped by the SÄá¹ƒkhyas,

or they would be many, like the many subtle atoms grasped as separate objects, or they would be many subtle atoms aggregated and accumulated, like the many subtle atoms grasped as all aggregated and accumulated as objects.
Moreover, external objects should not be unitary, because a substance with parts is different from the parts and cannot be grasped.
They are also not many, because individual subtle atoms cannot be grasped.
Moreover, they are not a composite or collection as objects, because a real, single subtle atom is not established.
How is it not established?
A verse says:ğŸ”½If a subtle atom combines with six, it should form six parts;
If it occupies the same place as six, the aggregate should be like a subtle atom.
The treatise says:
If a single subtle atom combines with six in each of the six directions, it should form six parts, because one place cannot contain another place.

If there are six atoms in the place of one subtle atom, the aggregate color should be the size of a subtle atom, because they do not exceed that size in relation to each other, and then the aggregate color would also be invisible.
The VaibhÄá¹£hikas of KaÅ›mÄ«ra say:
The meaning of aggregation does not apply to atoms, because they are partless, and one avoids the previous errors.
But the meaning of aggregation does apply to composite form, because it has spatial dimensions.
This is also unreasonable.
A verse says:
Since atoms have no aggregation, who has aggregation?
Or aggregation is not established, not because of partlessness.
The treatise says:
Now we should question the principle they have stated.
Since composite form is not separate from atoms, and atoms have no aggregation, who has aggregation?
If they further rescue their position by saying:
Composite form also has no meaning of aggregation.
Then they should not say:
Atoms have no aggregation because they are partless.
Composite form has spatial dimensions, but its aggregation is not accepted.
Therefore atoms have no aggregation, not because they are partless.
Therefore a single real atom is not established.
Moreover, accepting that atoms either aggregate or do not aggregate, their errors are as follows.
If you admit that the ultimate atom has parts or does not have parts, both are greatly mistaken.
Why is this?
The verse says:
If the ultimate atom has spatial parts, it should not be considered one;
If it has no spatial parts, there should be no shadow or obstruction, and the aggregation should not be different from the non-dual.
The treatise says:
If one ultimate atom has six different spatial parts, how can it be considered one?
If one ultimate atom has no different spatial parts, when the sun first rises and its light touches it, how can there be a shadow on the other side?
Because it has no other parts that are not reached by the light.
Moreover, for those who hold that the ultimate atom has no spatial parts, how can it obstruct the wheel that is extended from one place to another?
Because it has no other parts that are not traversed by others, one can say that they mutually obstruct each other from place to place.

Since they do not mutually obstruct each other, the places of all ultimate atoms should be the same, then all aggregated forms should have the same size as one ultimate atom, which is contrary to what has been said before.
Why do you not admit that shadow and obstruction belong to the aggregation and not to the ultimate atom?
How can it be that a shadow is produced by a collection of atoms, which are different from the atoms of the object?
If it is not so, then the collection must not have two parts.
That is to say, if the color of the collection is not different from the atoms, then the shadow must not belong to the color of the collection.
The atoms are established as having a different arrangement, or as a collection, but they are not a single real entity. Why bother to investigate whether the atoms or the collection are the object?
Still, you have not been able to refute the characteristics of external form, etc. What are the characteristics of these?
They are the objects of the eye, etc., and are also the real natures of blue, etc., and form, etc.
We must carefully consider whether these objects of the eye, etc., and the real natures of blue, etc., are one or many.
What is wrong with saying that they are either one or many?
Both positions are faulty. The faults of the position that they are many are as discussed above.
The position that they are one is also unreasonable.
A verse says:
One would have no sequential movement, and simultaneous arrival and non-arrival,
And many things with intervals, and difficulty seeing subtle objects.
The treatise says:

If there is no interval, then the objects of visual perception such as blue, which are grasped as a single entity, should not be gradually traversed, because one would reach all of them by moving one foot.
Moreover, one should simultaneously reach and not reach them.
It is unreasonable for a single entity to be both attained and not attained at the same time.

Moreover, in a single place, there should not be many elephants, horses, etc., with intervals between them. If a place has one, it should also have the others. How can they be distinguished as different?
Or how can there be both reaching and not reaching in a single place, with space seen in between?
Moreover, there should also be no small water insects and other subtle objects that are difficult to see, because they occupy the same place as gross objects and their size should be the same.
If it is said that they become separate objects due to differences in characteristics, not by other meanings,

Then you must definitely admit that this differentiated substance is further analyzed into many atoms. Since atoms have already been shown not to be real unities, then apart from consciousness, such things as the eye, form, etc., whether faculties or objects, are all shown not to exist.
Consequently, the doctrine of consciousness only is well established.
The existence or nonexistence of dharmas is determined by means of the means of valid knowledge. Among all the means of valid knowledge, direct perception is the most important.
If there is no external realm, how can there be this kind of consciousness?
I now directly experience such an object.
This proof is not established.
A verse says:
Direct perception is like dreams, etc. When the direct perception has already arisen,
The seeing and the object are already nonexistent. How can you admit that there is direct perception?
The treatise says:

Even though there are no external objects at the time of dreams, etc., one still has this kind of direct perception. You should understand that direct perception at other times is also like this. Therefore, the example they cite as proof is not established.
Moreover, if at that time there is this kind of direct perception, I now directly experience such form, etc.;
At that time, the seeing of the object is already absent, because it must be the mental consciousness that can discriminate, and the eye consciousness, etc., must have already ceased.

For those who advocate the doctrine of momentariness, when there is this awareness, the presently appearing objects such as form have also all ceased. How then can there be direct perception at this time?

It is only when one has previously experienced something that the mental consciousness can remember it. Therefore, it is certain that there are objects that have been experienced. The seeing of these objects is accepted as direct perception. From this, the meaning of the true existence of external objects is established.
In this way, it is necessary to prove the existence of external objects by first experiencing and then remembering them. This reasoning is also not established.
Why is this?
The verse states:
It is said that memory arises from consciousness that resembles the object.
The treatise states:

As previously explained, although there are no external objects, eye consciousness and so forth appear as if external objects. From this later stage onward, associated with memory, the discriminating mental consciousness appears as if the previous object were present. This is called remembering what was previously experienced. Therefore, the later memory does not prove that what was previously seen had real external objects.

If, as in a dream, consciousness can arise even though there are no real objects, then the same is true when awake.ğŸ”½Just as one knows by oneself that dream objects do not exist, so it is when awake. Why does one not know by oneself?
Since one does not know by oneself that the objects of the waking state do not exist, how can one say that, like the consciousness in a dream, the objects of the waking state are all nonexistent?
This is also not proof.
A verse says:
One who is not yet awake cannot know that what is seen in a dream does not exist.
The treatise says:
Just as one in a dream does not know that dream objects are not real external things, one only knows this when awake.

In the same way, the world is confused and deluded by the habitual force of false imagination, as if in a dream. Everything that is seen does not really exist, and one who has not attained true awakening is unable to know this by oneself.
When one attains the supramundane counteragent, non-discriminating cognition, this is called true awakening.
The pure mundane cognition attained subsequently, when present, truly understands that object to be unreal, and its meaning is equal.

If sentient beings, due to the transformation of their own mental continuum, give rise to cognition that appears as objects, and not due to external objects serving as objects, then for those sentient beings, whether associating with good or evil friends, hearing the correct or mistaken Dharma, the two cognitions are definitely established.
If there are no friends or teachings, how can this be established?
It is not that it cannot be established.
The verse says:
The two cognitions are definitely established by the power of mutual predominance.
The treatise says:

The consciousnesses of the series of self and others are mutually dominant conditions. The two consciousnesses are definitely so in accordance with their capacities. That is, because the consciousnesses of the series of others are different, they cause the consciousnesses of the series of self to be different, and each is definitely so, and not because of external objects.

If, as in a dream, the object is unreal but consciousness arises, then so it is in the waking state. Why is it that in dreams and the waking state, one performs good and bad actions, and the results of love and hate are not the same?
A verse says:
The mind is damaged by sleep, so the results of dreams and waking are not the same.
The treatise says:
The mind in the dream state is damaged by sleep, and its power is weak.
The waking mind is not like this. Therefore, the actions performed have different superior and inferior results, and are not due to external objects.
If there is only consciousness and no body, speech, etc., how can sheep, etc., be killed by others?
If the death of sheep, etc., is not due to the harm of others, how can the butcher obtain the sin of killing?
A verse says:
Due to the transformation of other's consciousness, there is the activity of killing,
Like the power of ghosts and spirits, causing others to lose mindfulness and so forth.
The treatise says:

Just as by the power of the intention and thoughts of ghosts and spirits, it causes other sentient beings to lose mindfulness, obtain dreams, or become possessed by spirits and so forth, resulting in strange events.

Those who possess spiritual powers, by the power of their intention and thoughts, cause others to see various things in their dreams, like the power of MahÄkÄtyÄyana's intention and wishes causing Åšrutasena and others to have strange dreams.
Also, like the power of the Ä€raá¹‡yaka sage's angry thoughts causing King BimbisÄra to have strange dreams.
In the same way, due to the transformation of other's consciousness, it causes the activity of harming the life faculty of others to arise.
One should know that death refers to the continuity of the aggregates, which is caused by the transformation of consciousness.
Next, a verse says:
How are the empty DantÄka and so forth due to the sage's anger?
Mental punishment is considered the greatest sin, but how is this established?
The treatise says:

If you do not admit that the death of sentient beings is due to the power of transformation of the consciousness of others, how then did the World-Honored One, in order to establish that mental punishment is a great sin, counter-question the elder UpÄli, saying:
Have you ever heard for what reason the forests of DantÄkÄ, MandÄkiá¹‡Ä«, and KarabhÄnaka all became desolate and silent?
The elder said to the Buddha:
Gautama!
I have heard it is because of the anger of the sages.

If you insist that the spirits and ghosts respect the sages and know to kill those sentient beings out of resentment, and it is not merely due to the anger of the sages, then how can you cite this to establish that mental punishment is a greater sin than bodily and verbal [actions]?
From this, you should understand that it is well established that those sentient beings died merely due to the anger of the sages.
If there is only consciousness, can the knowledge of others' minds know the minds of others?
If so, what is the error?
If one cannot know it, how can it be called knowledge of others' minds?
If one can know it, then consciousness-only should not be established.
Although one knows others' minds, it is not as it really is.
Verse:
How does knowledge of others' minds know its object as not as it really is?ğŸ”½Like the knowledge of one's own mind,
one does not know it as the Buddha's realm.
Commentary:
How does knowledge of others' minds know its object as not as it really is?
Like the knowledge of one's own mind.
How does this knowledge of one's own mind know its object as not as it really is?
Because of ignorance.
Because the two knowledges are each obscured by ignorance of their objects, they do not know the inexpressible realm experienced by the pure knowledge of the Buddha.
These two do not know their objects as they really are because they falsely appear as external objects and because the discrimination of grasped and grasper has not yet been eliminated.
The principle of consciousness-only has boundless determinations and distinctions, difficult to fathom and profound. Who but the Buddha could fully determine it in detail?
Verse:
I have already briefly established the meaning of consciousness-only according to my ability,
In this, all kinds are difficult to conceive, the practice of the Buddhas.
Commentary:
The categories of the principle of consciousness-only are boundless. I have already briefly established it according to my ability.
The rest of all kinds are inconceivable, because they transcend the realm of conceptual thought.
Such a principle is only practiced by the Buddhas. The World-Honored Buddhas, regarding all objects and all kinds, have unobstructed wisdom.
